questions.text: Which of the following is not included in pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.solution:
PID is caused by microorganisms colonizing the endocervix and ascending to the endometrium and fallopian tubes. It is a clinical diagnosis implying that the patient has upper genital tract infection and inflammation. The inflammation may be present at any point along a continuum that include endometritis, salpingitis, and peritonitis.

PID is commonly caused by the sexually transmitted microorganisms N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis.

Cervicitis and vaginitis are not included in PID.

Topic: Pelvic inflammatory disease

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 15, Page number. 893

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination, her secondary sexual characteristics, axillary and pubic hair present. There is absence of vagina. Her USG shows absence of uterus. Diagnosis for this patient is:
questions.solution:
Those girls who have mature secondary sex characteristics and any of a number of disorders of the outflow tract and uterus, often termed müllerian agenesis and dysgenesis, are most often identified on examination.

Normal secondary sexual characteristics and presence of axillary and pubic hair rules out option A and C.

There is absence of vagina and USG shows absence of uterus. So the correct option is D.

Topic: Mayer- Rokitansky- Kuster- Hauser syndrome

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 8, Page number:350

questions.text: 40-year-old patient came to OPD for treatment of PID. She has history of copper T insertion 1 year back. Which of the following is most common organism responsible for PID in this patient?
questions.solution:
• PID is caused by microorganisms colonizing the endocervix and ascending to the endometrium and fallopian tubes. It is a clinical diagnosis implying that the patient has upper genital tract infection and inflammation. The inflammation may be present at any point along a continuum that include endometritis, salpingitis, and peritonitis.
  • Most common organism causing PID: chlamydia
  • Most common PID due to IUCD: actinomyces
  • Most common cause of acute PID: gonorrhoea

Topic: Pelvic inflammatory disease organism

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 15, Page number. 893

questions.text: Ovulation occurs after how many hours of LH peak?
questions.solution:
• Ovulation: 24-36 hours after LH surge
  • Ovulation: 10-12 hours after LH peak
  • Before ovulation there is LH and FSH surge but ovulation occurs due to LH surge only.

Topic: Ovulation

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 7, Page number:. 122

questions.text: A 18-year-old female have complaint of lower abdominal pain for 2 days every month approximately 2 weeks before the menses. Most probable etiology is:
questions.solution:
• Functional cysts (e.g., follicle or corpus luteum) are the most common ovarian cysts and are more likely to rupture than benign or malignant neoplasms.
  • The pain associated with the rupture of the ovarian follicle at the time of ovulation is called mittelschmerz.
  • The small amount of blood leaking into the peritoneal cavity and high concentration of follicular fluid prostaglandins contribute to this mid cycle pelvic pain.
  • The pain is usually mild to moderate and self-limited, and with an intact coagulation system, hemoperitoneum is unlikely.
  • Mittelschmerz syndrome is painful ovulation due to rupture of the ovarian follicle at the time of ovulation.
  • History of pain in lower abdomen every month 2 weeks before the menstruation suggests mittelschmerz syndrome.

Topic: mittelschmerz syndrome

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 12, Page number:. 604

questions.text: Which of following is diagnostic of menopause?
questions.solution:
• Menopause, the permanent cessation of menstruation caused by ovarian failure, occurs at an average age of 52 years, with a range of 40 to 58 years.
  • Diagnostic criteria for menopause:
    • Serum FSH > 40IU/L
    • S. estrogen(E2) low – 10-20 pg/ml
    • S. estrone(E1) 30-70 pg/ml
    • E2/E1 <1

Topic: Menopause

Reference: Modern Gynecology by Ajit Virkud, 4th Edition, Chapter 29, Page number. 270

questions.text: Ferriman-gallway scoring system is used for:
questions.solution:
• Ferriman- gallway scoring system used for hirsutism.
  • It includes 9 sites- upper lip, chin, chest, upper back, lower back, upper abdomen, lower abdomen, upper arms, thighs.
  • Maximum score= 36
  • Rotterdam criteria is used for PCOS diagnosis.

Topic: Ferriman-gallway scoring system

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 36, Page number. 891

questions.text: Target gene for SRY which favours testis differentiation:
questions.solution:
Genes for testis development:

  • SOX-9, SF-1(steroidogenic factor)

Genes for ovary development:

  • WnT 4, Rspo 1, Dax 1
  • If the indifferent gonad is destined to become a testis, differentiation along this line will take place at 6-9 gestational weeks. The absence of testicular evolution (formation of medullary primary sex cords, primitive tubules, and incorporation of germ cells) gives implicit evidence of the existence of a primitive, albeit momentarily quiescent, ovary.

Topic: Genes for testis development

Reference: Leon Speroff's Gynecology, 9th Edition, Chapter 2, Page number. 165

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
• It is a straight metal cannula, 28 cm long with a fixed conical collar at the tip with spiral grooves over it and there is a Luer lock mount at the other end. This cannula is better suited for multiparous patients with a patulous cervix.
  • It is commonly used for chromopertubation and HSG.

questions.text: A 30-year-old P3L3 female comes on 5 days of unprotected sexual intercourse. What is the advice for contraception for this female?
questions.solution:
• Emergency contraception recommendation is it should be taken within 72 hours. Getest effect occurs when it is taken in 12 hours. It can be given upto 5 days.
  • Only copper IUDs can be used till 120 hours, but its efficacy is low.
  • Current recommendation is: treatment should be initiated as soon after exposure as possible but it should not be later than 120 hours.
  • Mifepristone in a single oral dose of 600 mg is associated with markedly less nausea and vomiting than with oral contraceptives and an efficacy rate of nearly 100%.
  • ulipristal acetate is slightly more effective than the single 1.5-mg dose of levonorgestrel when used within 72 hours after sexual intercourse and even between 72 and 120 hours.
  • Another method of emergency contraception is the insertion of a copper IUD, anytime during the preovulatory phase of the menstrual cycle and up to 5 days after ovulation. The failure rate (in a small number of studies) is very low,1%. 749,750 This method definitely prevents implantation, but it is not suitable for women who are not candidates for intrauterine contraception, for example, multiple sexual partners or a rape victim. The use of a copper IUD for emergency contraception is expensive, but not if it is retained as an ongoing method of contraception.

Topic: Emergency contraception

Reference: Leon Speroff's gynecology 8th edition, page number:. 1042

questions.text: Which of the following has least failure rate:
questions.solution:
• The Pearl Index, created by Raymond Pearl in 1933, is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure. The denominator is the total months or cycles of exposure from the onset of a method until completion of the study, an unintended pregnancy, or discontinuation of the method.
  • Life-table analysis calculates a failure rate for each month of use. A cumulative failure rate can then compare methods for any specific length of exposure.

Topic: Life-table analysis

Reference: Leon speroff, 9th Edition, chapter 24, table 24.1

choices.text: Development of cardiac failure in last month of pregnancy
Development of cardiac failure within 5 months after delivery

questions.text: Which of the following is not a diagnostic criterion of peripartum cardiomyopathy:
questions.solution:
Pearson (2000) reported findings of a workshop of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute that established the following diagnostic criteria:

  • Development of cardiac failure in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months after delivery.
  • Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure,
  • Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy,
  • Left ventricular systolic dysfunction demonstrated by classic echocardiographic criteria. These include depressed ejection fraction or fractional shortening along with a dilated left ventricle.

Topic: Diagnostic criterion of peripartum cardiomyopathy

Reference: William's Obstetrics, 25th edition, Chapter 49, Page number:. 963

questions.text: Cause of the following image characteristics:
questions.solution:
Image shows early deceleration.

  • Etiologically, head compression and dural stimulation probably cause vagal nerve activation, which mediates the FHR deceleration & seen in active labor between 4 and 7 cm cervical dilation.
  • In their definition, the degree of deceleration is generally proportional to the contraction strength and rarely falls below 100 to 110 bpm or 20 to 30 bpm below baseline.
  • These decelerations are common during active labor and not associated with tachycardia, loss of variability, or other FHR changes.
  • Early decelerations are considered benign and not associated with fetal hypoxia, acidemia, or low Apgar scores.
  • An early fetal heart rate deceleration characteristically shows a gradual decline and recovery in the heart rate that coincide with the onset and recovery of the contraction. The nadir of the deceleration is ≥30 seconds after the deceleration onset.

Topic: Head compression

Reference: William's Obstetrics, 25th edition, Chapter 24, Page number:465

questions.text: P3A0L3 female delivered a child 8 days back by vaginal delivery. Now she has complained of severe bleeding per vagina and diagnosed as secondary postpartum haemorrhage. Which of the following is the cause for this?
questions.solution:
• The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2017d) defines secondary postpartum hemorrhage as bleeding 24 hours to 12 weeks after delivery.
  • Clinically worrisome uterine hemorrhage develops within 1 to 2 weeks in perhaps 1 percent of women.
  • Such bleeding most often stems from abnormal involution of the placental site. It occasionally is caused by retention of placental fragments or by a uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Rarely, retained products may undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and neovascularization, thus forming a placental polypoid mass.
  • Severe hemorrhage occurs in only 6 percent of these cases due to rupture of blood vessels.
  • Delayed postpartum hemorrhage may also be caused by von Willebrand disease or other inherited coagulopathies.
  • In a stable patient, sonographic examination shows an empty cavity, then oxytocin, methylergometrine, or a prostaglandin analogue is given.

Topic: Secondary postpartum haemorrhage

Reference: William's Obstetrics, 25th edition, Chapter 36, Page number. 655

questions.text: A 24 years old pregnant woman, primigravida with gestational age of 18 weeks 5 days came to this opd with a complaint of backache for 2 days. She was an unbooked patient. She got her first ultrasound (level II) done at 18 weeks which revealed monochorionic diamniotic intrauterine live twins. Placenta was anterior with grade II maturity. Twin A Maturity 19 weeks 4 days with fetal weight of 850 grams. It had polyhydramnios with a single deepest pocket of 12 cm. Foetal kidneys were normal with distended urinary bladder. Twin B Maturity 16 weeks with fetal weight of 300 grams. It had marked oligohydramnios. Foetal kidneys and urinary bladder were still seen. The diagnosis of twin to twin transfusion syndrome was made with twin A as recipient twin and twin B as donor twin. What is management for this patient?
questions.solution:
• This scenario indicates TTTS (Twin To Twin Transfusion Syndrome). TTTS is diagnosed based on two sonographic criteria: First, a monochorionic pregnancy.
  • Second, hydramnios defined by a largest vertical pocket >8 cm in one sac and oligohydramnios defined by a largest vertical pocket <2 cm in the other twin are found. Growth discordance or growth restriction may be found with TTTS, but these per se are not considered diagnostic criteria.

It is typically classified by Quintero staging:

  • Stage I—discordant amniotic fluid volumes as described in the earlier paragraph, but urine is still visible sonographically within the bladder of the donor twin.
  • Stage II—criteria of stage I, but urine is not visible within the donor bladder.
  • Stage III—criteria of stage II and abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV—ascites or frank hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V—demise of either fetus.

Management:

  • stage 1- 2 weekly NST + BPP + USG.
  • Stage 2-4 – laser ablation of A –V anastomosis.
  • Stage 5 – delivery of the fetus.

Topic: Twin To Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

Reference: William's Obstetrics 26th edition, chapter45, page number:. 879

choices.text: Piper forceps- aftercoming head of breach

questions.text: Name and use of the following image:
questions.solution:
Image is showing piper forceps, which is specialized for use in the aftercoming head of breech.

Kielland Forceps

It is long rotational forceps with overlapping shanks. It has a sliding lock for correction of asynclitism of the fetal head. There are small knobs (buttons) over the handles.

Indications to use Kielland forceps:

  1. deep transverse arrest,
  2. persistent occipito-posterior.

Topic: Piper forceps

Reference: William's Obstetrics 26th edition, chapter 28, page number:. 547

questions.text: A primigravida patient came with full term pregnancy with labour pain with reactive NST. On per vaginal examination the cervix is 4 cm dilated, 50% effaced with membrane present. On doing rupture of membrane there is sudden intrauterine death of the fetus. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis for this condition is vasa previa.

  • With this condition, vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical os. There, they can be torn with cervical dilation or membrane rupture, and laceration can lead to rapid fetal exsanguination. Over the cervix, vessels can also be compressed by a presenting fetal part.
  • In case of placenta previa: there would be torrential bleeding and Per vaginal examination is contraindicated in it.
  • In case of placenta percreta there would be difficulty in separation of placenta and chances of postpartum haemorrhage is higher.
  • In case of abruption placenta, there would be passage of clots per vaginum plus the uterus would be tonically contracted, followed by decrease in Fetal heart rate.

Topic: vasa previa

Reference: William's Obstetrics 26th edition, chapter 6, page number. 119

questions.text: NT scan is done on:
questions.solution:
This represents the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck. The nuchal translucency is measured in the sagittal plane between 11 and 14 weeks' gestation using precise criteria:

And valid when CRL values lie between 38 to 45 mm.

Increased NT - A/W genetic syndromes and various birth defects especially cardiac defects.

If NT>= 3 mm patients should receive counselling and targeted fetal sonography with fetal echo and should be offered cffDNA.

Topic: Nuchal translucency

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, chapter 14, page number:. 281

choices.text: Start aspirin 150 mg with heparin 5000 iu BD

questions.text: A 4th gravida patient having 5 weeks of pregnancy came to a tertiary care hospital with a history of 3 previous abortions in the first trimester of pregnancy. She is positive for lupus anticoagulant and anticardiolipin antibodies but negative for anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibodies. At present she has no complaints. What is ideal for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Patient is having AntiPhosphoLipid Antibody syndrome(APLA).

For diagnosis of APLA:

1 clinical criteria and 1 laboratory criteria should be present for diagnosis.

Treatment for APLA with recurrent pregnancy loss: Aspirin 150 mg with heparin BD.

(Unfractionated heparin 5000 IU or LMWH 40 mg BD).

Topic: AntiPhosphoLipid Antibody syndrome (APLA)

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, chapter 59, page number:1145

questions.text: Hart line is present on:
questions.solution:
Hart line present on the inner surface of labia minora. Lateral portion of hart line is covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and the medial portion is covered by nonkeratinized squamous epithelium.

Topic: Hart line

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, chapter 2, page number:17
